headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: First Black Woman justice in Michigan; Complaints and Cancellations up Across Airline Industry; Family Makes it to NHL Winter Classic. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Welcome back, everyone, to CNN THIS MORNING.Here's what's coming up. History made in Michigan. We're going to hear from the state's first black female Supreme Court justice in moments. And nearly 3,000 miles and one week later, the family who drove from Phoenix to Boston for the NHL winter classic, they made it. They're going to join us live straight ahead. And just in, we are learning the suspect in the machete attack on NYPD officers in Times Square was interviewed by the FBI last month and had been on a terror watch list. That is according to our very own John Miller. More on that straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Well, now to a landmark moment at the Michigan Supreme Court. A black female justice has finally been sworn onto the state's highest court for the first time in its 185-year history.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JUSTICE KYRA HARRIS BOLDEN, MICHIGAN SUPREME COURT
utterances.sentences: And that I will faithfully discharge the duties

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Of the office of supreme court justice.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Of the office of supreme court justice.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: According to the best of my ability.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: According to the best of my ability.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That is Justice Kyra Harris Bolden. Her appointment comes at a very significant time for Michigan's supreme court. Just last year, the court had a number of key decisions. They ordered an abortion rights initiative to appear on the November ballot, they banned discrimination against LGBTQ people and ruled that one-person grand juries can't issue indictments against state officials. That's a big deal. And it led to charges being dismissed against the former governor in connection with the Flint water crisis.So, this term, the court also has a lot on its plate. And Justice Bolden's appointment is not only historic. Wait until you hear the story of her journey and her family's legacy of injustice in the hands of the legal system. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: JUSTICE KYRA HARRIS BOLDEN, MICHIGAN SUPREME COURT
utterances.sentences: One day this little girl came to me and said, Ms. Kyra, Ms. Kyra, can girls go to college?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: And I looked at her and I said, yes, I'm a girl. I'm in college. And she turns to the little girl next to her and says, see, I told you.HARLOW (voice over): Little girls saw themselves in Kyra Harris Bolden.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: This has been a long journey for all of us.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Today, for the first time, they can look up and see what else they could be.GOV. GRETCHEN WHITMER (D-MI): Kyra will be the first black woman ever to serve on the Michigan Supreme Court. Kyra.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And with that, history was made as Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer appointed Bolden to the state's highest court.

utterances.speaker: WHITMER
utterances.sentences: One hundred and eighty-five years we've never had an African American woman on the state's highest court. It's about damn time.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: It's just been an honor, and just been so surreal to be appointed to the highest court in the state of Michigan and be responsible for some really important decisions.HARLOW (on camera): What do you think makes you tear up?

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, because this means so much to so many people.HARLOW (voice over): Justice Bolden's journey to this court, though, began nearly a century ago with a tragedy.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Jesse Lee Bonds, my great grandfather, was lynched in Tennessee in 1939 after asking a store owner for a receipt. And he was beaten and castrated and thrown into the local river. And the coroner deemed it an accidental drowning. And, as a result, his murderers walked free.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That injustice drove Bolden to law school.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Once I realize that that was something that happened in my own family -HARLOW (on camera): Less than a hundred years ago.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. I just felt the need to be a part of the justice system and to go to law school and find my way in - in that.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: It was definitely a large part of it.HARLOW (voice over): She would go on to serve two terms in the state legislature and then take a leap, a chance at making history.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: We need to make sure that we have justices on our Michigan Supreme Court that believe in equal justice under the law.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She didn't win that race, but when a seat on the court opened up this summer, she was the governor's first choice.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you. And thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Her daughter, Emerson, not yet five months old, too young to know the history her mother has made.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Emerson, in just a few generations, our family has gone from lynching to law school, from injustice to a capital "j" justice.From injustice to capital "j" justice is really just -- it's just - it's amazing. It's amazing that we can make this type of progress for our family. HARLOW (on camera): What do you say to people who look at the state of racism in America today and don't see it as - as enough progress?

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: It's - it's not. It's not - it's not enough. It's absolutely unacceptable that in 2022 we are just now having the first black woman on the Michigan Supreme Court. There has never been a black woman that's been a governor in the United States history, right? It's not acceptable, but we still have to work hard and we still have to try to break down these barriers.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And 2022, it took till now to get the first black woman on the U.S. Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You know, when you think about Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, just a few months before you -

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What you think?

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think it's one of those moments where you know what's possible, right? You know, the same way that people have said that they look at me. The same way I look at her.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, she -- she's amazing, but she is a representation of what is possible.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Are we fired up?

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: Yes!

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: Are we ready to go?

utterances.speaker: CROWD
utterances.sentences: Yes!HARLOW (voice over): Justice Bolden will be unique on this court, as the only justice who was previously a state lawmaker. HARLOW (on camera): So that also, though, opens the door to other critics who say, well, you're a Democrat, you're partisan, you know, you've served in the legislature. You ran as a Democrat. How do you shed that?

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: All judges and justices have personal points of view. You know, so I don't think I'm different in that. My job, as a justice, is to interpret the laws.We have the opportunity to protect justice for generations to come. Did you know that? HARLOW (voice over): In a fitting full circle, she will fill the seat of Chief Justice Bridget McCormack, whose campaign was the first she worked on a decade ago.

utterances.speaker: BRIDGET MCCORMACK, FORMER CHIEF JUSTICE, MICHIGAN SUPREME COURT
utterances.sentences: The state is getting a smart, savvy, and hardworking public servant as its newest justice.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: I know the weight of this job. I know what it means. It's always been my goal to pull people with me. You know, Vice President Kamala said, maybe the first but not the last, right?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLDEN
utterances.sentences: And that's just kind of the mantra that - that I live by.(END VIDEOTAPE) HARLOW: What a - what an honor to sit with her. And, you know, I have to mention, Alpha Kappa Alpha.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: AKA.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Alpha Kappa Alpha. We talked so much about the barriers that she's breaking for AKA, along with, you know, following the likes of Vice President Kamala Harris, Toni Morrison and so many more.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. And, look, that part is important because when you think about the black sororities, the impact that they have on elections around the country, and not only just for women. Like, they get people -- they get out the vote. In Louisiana, the last gubernatorial election, the black sororities really helped in a red state, pushed and helped to elect a Democratic governor there.But she is --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: A force. Thirty-four only.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Amazing.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I want to say one thing. She has a five-month-old baby.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So she ran this campaign pregnant, crisscrossing the state.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And as someone who has had babies, I - just doing any job, let alone that job is difficult. Her husband took two months paternity leave and was an equal caregiver at home so that she could do that. We talk a lot about what it takes to lift people up.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Big part of this for her she said as well having that equal partner.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm not so surprised that she did this pregnant. What did - what did they say about Ginger Rogers, she had to do everything that Fred Astaire did but backwards and in heels.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, women, amazingly can do those things.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Guys are, you know, we're not - we're not there yet.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Our thanks to her. It was really a delight to get to spent some time with her.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What? Hmm?(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You heard about the meltdown last week. Perhaps you were part of it. The meltdown by Southwest Airlines leaving passengers angry and stranded. But what is the public perception of the entire industry, the entire airline industry these days?CNN's senior data reporter, Mr. Harry Enten, joins us with the number this morning. When you said what the number was before -

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I thought you were talking about the weight I gained on vacation, but it's not about me.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You look great.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: You look fantastic.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Go on. No, go on. Three hundred and six?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What's funny, Harry?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: The fact of the matter is, is that people used to really like the airline industry. The favorable and positive use of the airline industry was 67 percent back in 1969.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That's when people used to actually wear clothes on airplanes and dress up.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I mean they gave you like china and meals and champagne.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: They did.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait, they don't do that anymore?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: They do not do that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Sorry. Oh, that's only in first class.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: They don't do that anymore. And, you know, if you look, how are airlines cutting costs? A few of a number of ways. The size of the seats have dropped.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: The leg room is dropping. Amenities like airplane food have all but disappeared.But how do they keep you? How do they keep you basically going to -- taking those planes? Because look at the price of the airline if you -- for a round trip ticket.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow. There you go.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Now just $367. It's been dropping. So, it gets you in with those cheap prices and then basically take away all the amenities.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. All right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Harry.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Three hundred and six.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Speaking of airlines, after their Southwest flight was canceled on Christmas Day, one Phoenix family decided to drive nearly 3,000 miles to make their son's Christmas wish come true.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Very excited about this.An update now on a story we brought you last week. You may remember the Maher family, whose Southwest flight was canceled on Christmas Day. Well, they decided to rent a truck and drive 3,000 miles nearly from Phoenix to Boston to fulfill their eldest son's single holiday wish to go to the NHL Winter Classic in Boston. When we last spoke with them, they were starting on the last leg of their journey. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) KELLEY MAHER, DROVE FROM PHOENIX TO BOSTON TO ATTEND TODAY'S NHL WINTER CLASSIC: When we made the decision in Terminal 4 in Sky Harbor on Sunday to turn this into a drive, you know, I remember my husband saying, guys, this is a really big commitment. Is everybody up for this? And I - I think probably secretly we were dreading it a little bit. But we actually have laughed a lot and had lots of smiles. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And they made it. And they're here joining us live from Boston, from Fenway.Tim, Kelley, Beauwin, Sullivan (ph), Sailor (ph), and Ireland. Congrats. How is it, guys? KELLEY MAHER, DROVE FROM PHOENIX TO BOSTON TO ATTEND TODAY'S NHL WINTER CLASSIC: We made it. It's amazing.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Just like -TIM MAHER, DROVE FROM PHOENIX TO BOSTON TO ATTEND TODAY'S NHL WINTER CLASSIC: An amazing experience. BEAUWIN "BO" MAHER, FAMILY DROVE 3,000 MILES TO ATTEND TODAY'S NHL WINTER CLASSIC: Yes, fantastic.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, are you warm? I mean, you know, it's cold -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, at least they're wearing jackets or not stuck in a car.Overall, I meant, are you warm? B. MAHER: I - I am freezing. I am. They - they didn't give me a jacket. K. MAHER: Our Phoenix blood, our thin Phoenix - our New England friends from childhood are just nodding at us in disbelief that we're bundled up like this. But we're freezing.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK. So, Beauwin, this was your dream, right? This was your - now whose - whose - whose -B. MAHER: That's right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. OK, so you are the reason your family took this epic trip. But you're also the reason that some amazing things have been happening to your family. What's it been like?B. MAHER: It's been like surreal. I still can't believe some of the things we've done. I'm still like inhaling and digesting everything we've done. I mean it's like -- the NHL just kept like one-upping themselves. They're like, we want to give you this. And we're like, oh my gosh, thank you. And then they're like, we want to give you this. We're like, oh, my gosh, thank you. Oh my -- like, no, please, you're too kind. It's - it's just great. K. MAHER: He said yesterday, at the end of the day, we were finishing up dinner and he said, my face hurts from smiling so much today. B. MAHER: My cute little dimples.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What did they give you? What did they give you?B. MAHER: Oh - K. MAHER: Well, who did you dine with last night? B. MAHER: Well, we went to Ray Bourque's restaurant. And he came around the corner. And, like, it was like that like ah-ha moment. Like, we just made eye contact. And I was like, oh, my gosh. And then he came over and he gave me a signed jersey. And I just -- I was smiling for probably like six minutes straight. I mean my cheekbones were so strained. It was - yes. And - yes, it was just crazy. K. MAHER: And during the day we had a tour of Fenway, which was incredible. I mean for us, growing up here, we moved to Arizona about 20 years ago. But growing up here, I mean it was iconic walking around and seeing the back hallways and that sort of thing. Then we came back for the Bruins practice. And Beauwin and Sully (ph) got to stand where the players were coming in and fist bump with all of them. And just being so up close and being able to have that sort of vantage point of them practicing, these athletes that we just think are incredible, and cheer on from our TV screens at home, it's just been incredible. I mean we are -- we're Irish and we're not speechless very often and we've been pretty speechless.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.OK, so, well, speaking of Stanley Cup, right, and Ray Bourque, the NHL wanted to surprise you and give you a chance to be with the Stanley Cup, too, right? B. MAHER: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, look - look to your right or your left or something.K. MAHER: Look at - look at - look. B. MAHER: Oh -

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What?B. MAHER: There she is. Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Sully, touch it.K. MAHER: (INAUDIBLE). Sullivan last night was asking Ray Bourque, as if he was our neighbor, chatting with him like he was a regular old guy, while we were all gob smacked. And he said to Ray Bourque, is the Stanley Cup very heavy? T. MAHER: And we know who you are. K. MAHER: And Ray said, yes, and they kept wanting me to lift it over my head. My arms were very tired.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Who's the little guy - what's the little guy closet to the couple.T. MAHER: That's incredible. That's incredible.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Look at his face. Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).K. MAHER: So, this is Sullivan. We call him Sully. He's named after Sullivan Square here in Boston. T. MAHER: He - he draws pictures of the Stanley Cup all the time at home. And this is incredible. It's - it's - it's awesome. K. MAHER: Oh, my gosh. Unreal. T. MAHER: Wow. K. MAHER: Thank you so much. B. MAHER: I want to touch it. I want to -

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right, guys, as if today -- as if this isn't enough -- what did you say, Sully?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: He's not mic'd, but - HARLOWK. MAHER: Say that part again? Sorry.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK. So, listen, this - we've another surprise for you. The NHL is gifting your family with tickets to the NHL Winter Classic in 2024. So you're going to make this trip again, guys.B. MAHER: Oh, my gosh. K. MAHER: Stop it!

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. This is what happens -B. MAHER: Another road trip. Another road trip. K. MAHER: (INAUDIBLE) 2024. T. MAHER: We get to do another road trip next year.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: This is what happens when you appear on CNN THIS MORNING, people.K. MAHER: Oh my gosh.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Careful what you promise.B. MAHER: That's right, baby. T. MAHER: I know. This is incredible. It's - K. MAHER: Happy, hockey family. T. MAHER: Right. K. MAHER: Incredible. Thank you so much. B. MAHER: Yes. Oh, my gosh. T. MAHER: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We're so happy for you guys. Have the best time today.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. And go inside and warm up, OK? Congratulations. Happy New Year to you.K. MAHER: It's hard to think yesterday can be topped, but thank you. Happy New Year. T. MAHER: Happy New Year. Thank you so much. Wow.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Bye, guys. What a great family.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Tim, Beauwin, Sullivan, Sailor, Ireland, we are very happy for you.OK, so, the Boston Bruins are going to face the Pittsburg Penguins in the 2023 Discover NHL Winter Classic at Fenway Park. TNT's coverage of the game is going to begin at 1:00 p.m. Eastern Time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Can we just end every show, and you get one, and you get one, and you get one, and you get one, and you get one.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And you get one. And you get a car. And you get a car. Well, that's another show.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We will see you tomorrow, maybe with a car giveaway.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's someone - yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That would be -- you need it with the airlines, what's happening with the airlines.Bye, everybody.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: CNN "NEWSROOM" is now.
